p: Considering the departure of the current climate from that of the early to mid-Holocene, when most peatlands were formed [ 22– 24], it is not clear how climate change might affect Sphagnum species (the dominant peat-forming group) and Sphagnum peatland distributions in general. Some studies suggest that warming could enhance carbon sequestration by increasing Sphagnum net primary productivity [ 25], [ 26]. However, other findings indicate that carbon sequestration could decrease [ 27] because warming is expected to relax constraints on microbial decomposition, which would cause a decline in the carbon storage in northern peatlands [ 28– 30].
